title-group.article-title: Effect of storage time and natural corrosion inhibitor on carbohydrate and carboxylic acids content in canned tomato purée

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Food Technology and Biotechnology, University of Zagreb, Pierottijeva, Zagreb, Croatia
2Stazione Sperimentale per l`Industria delle Conserve Alimentari, Via Nazionale, Angri (SA), Italy

author-notes.corresp: A Ninčević Grassino, Faculty of Food Technology and Biotechnology, University of Zagreb, Pierottijeva, Zagreb, Croatia Email: aninc@pbf.hr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this research compositional changes of tinplate-canned tomato purées, with or without the addition of essential onion oil were investigated. The study was focused on the analyses of carbohydrates and carboxylic acids in two groups of canned samples (with or without nitrates) to determine whether their chemical composition was affected with storage time. The measurements were performed by high performance liquid chromatography, during six months of storage. The contents of glucose, fructose and two major organic acids, citric and malic, were found in the concentration range 1.77–1.97%, 1.86–2.09%, 0.60–0.75% and 0.23–0.30%, respectively, in all canned samples. Compared to carbohydrates and organic acids, amino acids were found in minor quantities, among them, as most abundant ones were glutamic acid, arginine, aspartic and γ-amino butyric acids. The results show that contents of carbohydrates and carboxylic acids are significantly affected by the change of storage time in majority of analyzed samples. The results also indicated that the influence of essential onion oil on composition of canned tomato purée is within the range of changes due to storage time measured for all other types of cans. Therefore the addition of essential onion oil as natural efficient corrosion inhibitor, as it was found in our previous work, can be recommended for canned tomato purée.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum L.) is one of the most widely cultivated vegetable crops in Mediterranean countries. Significant amounts are consumed in the form of processed products, i.e. tomato juice, paste, purée, ketchup, sauce and salsa. Tomato and tomato-based products are reservoir of diverse antioxidant molecules such as ascorbic acid, vitamin E, carotenoids, flavonoids and phenolic acids (Binoy et al., 2004; Chu et al., 2000; Toor and Savage, 2006). Its consumption is associated with a reduced risk of different types of cancer. In addition, the tomato contains a complex mixture of sugars, organic acids, amino acids and volatile compounds, which contribute to the characteristic flavor of tomato fruit. Carbohydrates and carboxylic acids are playing the major role in the sweet-sour taste of tomato (Abegaz et al., 2004; Salles et al., 2003; Tandon et al., 2003; Yilmaz, 2001). The sugars that mostly contribute to sweetness perception are glucose and fructose, while sour taste is mainly attributed to citric and malic acids. The taste compositional data of tomato varies due to the wide range of species, stage of ripeness, year of growth, climatic conditions, light, temperature, soil, fertilization, irrigation and other conditions of cultivation, handling and storage.

Analysis of these individual components is of capital importance, because they preclude some relevant safety, nutrition, physicochemical and sensorial properties of tomato and tomato-based products. Different analytical techniques such as spectrophotometry (Bucheli et al., 1999; Martínez-Barajas, 2003) and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Boggio et al., 2000; Del Valle et al., 2006; Osvald et al., 2001; Paredes et al., 2008; Roselló et al., 2002; Sajur et al., 2007; Tandon et al., 2003;) have been extensively used for the determination of taste-active compounds in raw tomato.

As noted, the knowledge about the effects of industrial processing occurring in tomato was limited to some compounds. For example, carotenoids and vitamin C were measured in tomato purée subjected to high pressure, low and high pasteurization and freezing (Sánchez-Moreno et al., 2006). The effect of homogenization and thermal processing on a number of bioactive compounds such as carotenoids, total phenolic, ascorbic acid and folates in raw and “hot break” tomato purée were investigated by Pérez-Conesa et al. (2009). Rajchl et al. (2009) evaluated the changes of selected markers (furosine, 2-furaldehyde, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furaldehyde) during the pasteurization of tomato purée and ketchup. Ordóñez-Santos (2008) measured the total and soluble solids, water activity, lycopene, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural, total acidity, ascorbic acid and pH to assess the quality of final manufactured products, i.e. crushed tomato, tomato purée and paste, double and triple concentrate. These studies do not report the stability of analyzed micronutrients, or physico-chemical variables in processed tomato during storage. Ordóñez-Santos et al. (2009) reported the stability of lycopene, β-carotene, organic acids (malic, ascorbic and citric), total phenolics and 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural in bottled tomato pulp stored at 20 °C, during 180 days of storage.

In our previous papers (Ninčević Grassino et al., 2009a, 2009b, 2010) essential onion oil (EOO) was found to be a very efficient natural tin corrosion inhibiting substance. Thus the aim of this article was (1) to measure the changes of the chemical composition according to the storage time and temperature and (2) to evaluate the influence of EOO addition on chemical composition of canned tomato product during storage time and temperature.

sec.title: Reagents and solutions
sec.p: All reagents were of pro analysis quality. Deionized water purified by Millipore-MilliQ system was used for preparation of reagents and standards.
The EOO was provided by Aromi Mediterranei VI.SA. S.r.l., Nocera Inferiore, (SA), Italy.

Commercial standard solutions of glucose, fructose and sucrose obtained from Sigma (St Louis, MO, USA) and oxalic, citric, galacturonic, succinic, lactic, acetic, 3-oxo-glutaric and malic acids obtained from Carlo Erba Reagenti (Milano, Italy) were used for HPLC analysis of carbohydrates and organic acids.

High purity amino acid calibration standard (Amino Acid Standard H) purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. (Rockford, USA) was used for HPLC analysis of amino acids. Standard solutions of asparagine, glutamine and γ-amino butyric acid obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Inc. (St. Louis, MO, USA) and β-amino butyric acid (BABA) obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemie GmbH (Buchs, Switzerland) were also used for HPLC analysis of amino acids. AccQ-FluorTM Reagent Kit with AccQ-FluorTM Borate Buffer, AccQ-FluorTM Reagent Powder and AccQ-FluorTM Reagent Diluent purchased from Waters (Milford, USA) were used for derivatization of amino acids.
Sodium acetate trihydrate, SigmaUltra, ≥99% and ethylene-di-amine-tetra-acetic acid di-sodium salt dihydrate, SigmaUltra, ∼99% were provided by Sigma-Aldrich Inc. (St. Louis, MO, USA).
Sodium azide and phosphoric acid (85%) were provided from Farmitalia Carlo Erba, S.p.a. (Milano, Italy).
Hydrochloric acid and acetonitrile were supplied by Merck KGaA (Darmstadt, Germany). Ammonia solution (28%) was provided by Carlo Erba Reagenti (Milano, Italy).

sec.title: Instruments
sec.p: For determination of carbohydrates Waters 600E chromatographic system (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA) with Waters 410 refractive index detection (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA) was used. The Millenium 32 (version 3.05.01) software was used for the control, data acquisition and processing.

Organic and amino acids were determined with Waters Alliance (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA) chromatographic system, equipped with UV-VIS and fluorescence detector (Varian, model 320). The Waters Empower software was used for the control, data acquisition and processing during analyses of organic acids and amino acids.

sec.title: Can filling
sec.p:
The tinplate cans with different tin coating masses, type D11.2/2.8 g/m2 (Italian Norm, 2004a) were supplied by Impress, S.p.a., Cava de’Tirreni, Italy. They were filled with tomato purée (net mass of 420–450 g), provided by La Doria, S.p.a., Angri, Italy and prepared for analysis as described in our previous papers (Ninčević Grassino et al., 2009b, 2010). All cans were separated in two main groups: (I) filled with tomato purée and nitrates and (II) filled with tomato purée (Table 1). Each group of cans was packed with: (i) dioctyl sebacate (DOS) oil, normally used in food canning (Italian Norm, 2004b), 3–7 mg/m2 (as obtained by supplier), (ii) EOO sprayed on tinplate (36 mg/m2) and (iii) EOO added directly to tomato purée (0.10 g per can). The second (ii) and third (iii) group of cans were prepared without DOS oil, i.e. the layer of DOS oil on fabricated tinplate sheets (92.5 × 91.2 cm2) was washed with acetone. Afterwards a dry tinplate sheets for the second group of cans were sprayed with EOO by aerograph (Valex, S.p.a., Schio, Italy) at pressure of 1–2 bar. All cans were then sterilized at 100 °C for 20 min, cooled and stored at 20 °C or 36 °C until analyses. Table 1.
Description of can filling conditions
Can type code Description of can type code name
I group AN nitrate + DOS oil
BN nitrate + EOO sprayed on tinplate
BN 0.1 g nitrate + EOO added to product
II group ASN without nitrate + DOS oil
BSN without nitrate + EOO sprayed on tinplate
BSN 0.1 g without nitrate + EOO added to product
DOS oil: dioctyl sebacate oil; EOO: essential onion oil.

sec.title: Can sampling
sec.p: Samples were taken from cans at different time intervals between 30 and 180 days. During the storing period the content of carbohydrates, organic acids and amino acids in canned tomato purée was determined. For all chromatographic analyses the samples (25 g) were dissolved in deionized water to a final volume of 100 mL. After 20 min of extraction, the suspensions were centrifuged (BHG HERMLE ZK 401) for 15 min at 8000 or 12,000 r/min (only for amino acid determination) and the supernatant was filtered through a filter paper and Millipore filters (0.45 µm pore size).

sec.title: Determination of carbohydrates, organic and amino acids in canned tomato purée with HPLC
sec.p: Simple and rapid HPLC analysis of main group of carbohydrates and carboxylic acids involved in canned tomato purée taste as an important quality parameter was performed. The validation of analysis method (Accredia, 2002) and matrix effect on the concentration obtained has been already investigated (De Sio et al., 1995; Villari et al., 1994; Silvestri et al., 1992a, 1992b).

The HPLC system for analyses of carbohydrates was equipped with Sugar PackTM column, 6.5 mm × 300 mm (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA). The temperature of column was 90 °C. The EDTA dihydrate (50 mg/L) was used as a mobile phase at the flow-rate of 2 mL/min. The pressure was 500 psi. The standard solutions of glucose, fructose and sucrose of 0.10%, 0.20% and 0.40% (mass per volume) were prepared with Milli-Q water. The volume of samples and standards injected into HPLC system was 10 µL.

The organic acids were quantified by HPLC with a Shodex IonPack KC-811 column (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA). The temperature of column was 35 °C. The compounds were eluted with phosphoric acid (0.10 vol%) at the flow-rate of 1 mL/min. The pressure was 712 psi. The standard solution mixtures (mass per volume) of oxalic acid (0.05%), citric acid (0.50%), galacturonic acid (0.30%), succinic acid (0.50%), lactic acid (0.50%), acetic acid (0.50%), 3-oxo-glutaric acid (0.10%) and malic acid (0.50%) were prepared with Milli-Q water. The volume of samples and standards injected into HPLC system was 5 µL.

HPLC analyses were carried out for the determination of amino acids. The protocol recommended by Strydom and De Sio (Strydom and Cohen, 1994; De Sio et al., 1995) is briefly described. Separation was performed on AccQ TagTM column; 3.9 mm × 150 mm (Waters, Milford, Massachusetts, USA). Column temperature was 35 °C. The mobile phase consisted of eluent A: C2H3O2Na·3H2O (c = 140 mM), EDTA·2H2O (c = 5 mM) and NaN3 (0.10%, mass per volume), eluent B: acetonitrile and eluent C: Milli-Q water. Prior to HPLC analysis, the samples were purified with AG 50 W-X8 column (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc., Hercules, CA, USA). The calibration standard solution was composed of Amino Acid Standard H (c = 2.5 mM), asparagine (c = 2.5 mM), glutamine (c = 2.5 mM), γ-amino butyric acid (c = 2.5 mM) and β-amino butyric acid (c = 2.5 mM) as internal standard. The calibration standard and purified samples were derived with AccQ-FluorTM Reagent before injection into HPLC system. The injected volume of each was 5 µL.

Chromatographic peaks were identified by comparing retention times with those of standards. External standard method for determination of carbohydrates and organic acids and standard addition method for determination of amino acids were used. To assess the accuracy of the determination quantification of amino acids was done by spiking of standard solutions and some samples with recoveries are presented in Table 5. All results are expressed as mass fractions (w/%) of determined analyte (mass of analyte in g (or mg) per 100 g of sample).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The STATGRAPHIC Centurion XV statistical package, Version 15 (Stat Point, Virginia, USA) was applied to compare which mean values are significantly different from one another. The comparison was done by multiple range tests. Differences were considered to be significant when p < 0.05.

sec.title: Determination of carbohydrates in canned tomato purée
sec.p:
Sugars glucose and fructose in canned tomato purée stored at 20 °C for 180 days were identified and quantified by HPLC (Table 2). Table 2.
Mass fractions of glucose wG and fructose wF in canned tomato purée samples stored at 20 °C

30 60 120 180
wG (%)

wF (%)

BSN 2.07 ± 0.03 a, B 2.05 ± 0.00 a, AB 1.94 ± 0.01 b, A 1.93 ± 0.00 b, AB

AN: cans with nitrates and DOS oil; BN: cans with nitrates and EOO sprayed on the tinplate; ASN: cans with DOS oil and without nitrates; BSN: cans with EOO sprayed on the tinplate and without nitrates; BN 0.1 g: cans with nitrates and EOO added to tomato purée; BSN 0.1 g: cans with EOO added to tomato purée and without nitrates.
Mean ± SD (n = 3). Results in the same row followed by the same small letter are not significantly different among storage time (p < 0.05). Results in the same column followed by the same capital letters are not significantly different among the types of canned tomato purée samples (p < 0.05).

The sucrose was not found, which is in agreement with previous reports that sucrose is not present in tomato fruit (Roselló et. al., 2002) or is found in minor quantity, about 0.05% (Osvald et al., 2001). Sucrose has an important role in development of tomato plant, but during ripening of tomato fruit is converted to glucose and fructose (Obiadalla-Ali et al., 2004). It is observed that the period of highest accumulation of hexose in fruit starts after reaching the mature green stage (Martínez-Barajas, 2003).

The ratio of glucose and fructose is an important data in the authenticity test of fruits (Hernández Suárez et al., 2008a). In tomato, this ratio must be around 0.8–1. From our data (Table 2), the calculated ratios for canned tomato purées are between 0.91 and 0.96.

The results presented in Table 2 show that mass fractions of glucose ranged from 1.77% to 1.97% in canned samples. The lower contents of glucose were found in the canned tomato purées with EOO and without nitrates (BSN 0.1 g). It can be noticed that mass fraction of glucose in cans with EOO added to tomato purée (BN 0.1 g and BSN 0.1 g) or sprayed onto tinplate surface (BN), and in cans with DOS oil and without nitrates (ASN), did not change during storage period; i.e. no significant differences were found between 30 and 180 days of sampling. On the other hand, significant differences (p < 0.05) of glucose mass fractions between storage days were found in two other analyzed samples (AN and BSN, Table 2).

The contents of most abundant monosaccharide fructose were in the range between 1.86% and 2.09% in all analyzed cans (Table 2). Between sampling days in almost all analyzed cans, except in cans with EOO added to the product (BN 0.1 g and BSN 0.1 g), the significant difference (p < 0.05) of fructose mass fractions was found.
On the other hand within the same storage day mass fractions of glucose and fructose were significantly different (p < 0.05), regardless of can type.

sec.title: Determination of organic acids in canned tomato purée
sec.p:
In our analyzed canned tomato purée samples citric acid was the major organic acid, as found in the literature for other tomato products and tomato fruit (Hernández Suárez et al., 2008b; Osvald et al., 2001; Salles et al., 2003) followed by malic and succinic acids. The mass fractions of citric acid were found in the range from 0.60% to 0.75% in all analyzed cans, stored at 20 °C (Table 3). The second major organic acid in canned tomato purées is malic acid with mass fractions found from 0.23% to 0.30% (Table 3). Table 3.
Mass fractions of citric and malic acids (wCA and wMA) in canned tomato purée samples stored at 20 °C

BSN 0.27 ± 0.01 a, AB 0.26 ± 0.00 a, BC 0.26 ± 0.00 a, AB 0.29 ± 0.00 a, A

AN: cans with nitrates and DOS oil; BN: cans with nitrates and EOO sprayed on the tinplate; ASN: cans with DOS oil and without nitrates; BSN: cans with EOO sprayed on the tinplate and without nitrates; BN 0.1 g: cans with nitrates and EOO added to tomato purée; BSN 0.1 g: cans with EOO added to tomato purée and without nitrates.
Mean ± SD (n = 3). Results in the same row followed by the same small letter are not significantly different among storage time (p < 0.05). Results in the same column followed by the same capital letters are not significantly different among the types of canned tomato purée samples (p < 0.05).

The results have shown that statistically significant differences (p < 0.05) were detected in the citric and malic acids contents between 30 and 180 days of storage. Thus, it can be concluded that mass fractions of these two organic acids are affected by storage time.

It should be noticed that with the increase of shelf-life period, mass fraction of citric acid in cans with EOO added to tomato purée (BN 0.1 g and BSN 0.1 g) was higher (18% to 21%) compared with all other canned samples (lower than 5%). Also, the increase of mass fraction of malic acid with storage time is less expressed (lower than 12%) in canned samples with DOS oil (AN and ASN), and EOO sprayed on tinplate surface (BN and BSN). In particular, no significant change of malic acid during storage was found in BSN cans. The effect of storage time on malic acid content is pronounced in cans with EOO added to tomato purée (BN 0.1 g and BSN 0.1 g), where mass fractions increased for 25% (BN 0.1 g) and 21% (BSN 0.1 g), from 30 to 180 days of storage. The values obtained for citric and malic acid in cans with EOO added to purée are still acceptable compared to the literature where 0.44% of malic and 0.85% of citric acids (Hernández Suárez et al., 2008b; Salles et al., 2003) in tomato was reported.

The mass fractions of succinic and 3-oxo-glutaric acid are found in a very narrow range (0.23–0.28% and 0.16–0.19%, respectively) in all types of canned tomato purées. Storage time significantly influence (p < 0.05) the contents of both acids (Table 4). Table 4.

Concerning the cans type within the same storage day (Tables 3 and 4), it can be observed that contents of citric, malic, succinic and 3-oxo-glutaric acids were significantly different (p < 0.05) in majority of analyzed canned tomato purées, while for succinic and 3-oxo-glutaric acids no significant difference was observed on 120th day of storage.

sec.title: Determination of amino acids in canned tomato purée
sec.p: As EOO is a potential natural corrosion inhibitor, composition of free amino acids and influence of storing time, were studied in cans with EOO added to tomato purée (BN 0.1 g and BSN 0.1 g). The results were compared with canned tomato purée samples with DOS oil (AN and ASN), normally used for food canning. Free amino acids were analyzed in samples stored at 36 °C, because at that temperature the kinetics of oxidation and reduction increases four times compared to the same process at 20 °C (Ninčević Grassino et al., 2009b, 2010). All samples were spiked with standards and in Table 5 results of the spiking studies are presented. Good recoveries were obtained in each sample suggesting that the method is accurate enough. Method reproducibility was evaluated by making three injections of each sample and each spiked sample.

The identified free amino acids in canned tomato purées are presented in Table 6. The data reveal that glutamic, aspartic and γ-amino butyric acids and arginine were found in major amounts. According to the literature (Kader et al., 1978; Loiudice et al., 1995) glutamic, aspartic, and γ-amino butyric acids and glutamine, represent around 80% of total free amino acids in ripened tomato fruit. Glutamine is the second major amino acid in tomato fruit (Boggio et al., 2000) or tomato juice (Salles et al., 2003), after glutamic acid. In processed tomato canned samples investigated in this article glutamine was found in a very low concentration, compared to the values reported for tomato fruit (Porretta, 1991). The obtained results can be explained with the fact that glutamine is converted, during fresh tomato processing, to glutamic acid and after successive deamination to pyroglutamic and pyrolindone carboxylic acids. Generally, the content of free amino acids is constant during tomato fruit ripening, while in processing tomato the content of free amino acids is changed. Partial hydrolysis of protein increases particularly glutamic and aspartic acids, alanine and treonine contents, while glutamine is diminished. Table 6.
Mass fractions of amino acids wAA in canned tomato purée samples stored at 36 °C

AN: cans with nitrates and DOS oil; ASN: cans with DOS oil and without nitrates; BN 0.1 g: cans with nitrates and EOO added to tomato purée; BSN 0.1 g: cans with EOO added to tomato purée and without nitrates.
Mean ± SD (n = 3). Results in the same row followed by the different small letter are significantly different among storage time (p < 0.05). Results in the same column followed by the different capital letters are significantly different among the types of canned tomato purée samples (p < 0.05).
ND: not detected.

Arginine, aspartic acid and asparagine were found in the range between 75.9 and109.7, 62.2 and 86.1, and 29.1 and 40.4 mg/100 g, respectively, depending on the can type. All other amino acids were found in lower amounts.

The contents of serine, threonine and phenylalanine were found between 9.6 and 17.0 mg/100 g in all analyzed tomato purées. Compared with these three amino acids, alanine, histidine, lysin, valine, leucine, isoleucine, tyrosine, glycine and methionine were determined in minor quantities, while cysteine was found in traces (Table 6).

The statistical analyses of free amino acids denote that differences among storage time as well as the types of canned tomato purée samples within same storage day were significant. Compared to carbohydrates and organic acids the influence of storage time is more expressed in the case of free amino acids because they are more prone to chemical transformations, such as hydrolysis and deamination.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Chemical compositions of carbohydrates and carboxylic acids were determined in two main groups of canned tomato purée samples, with or without addition of nitrate, by HPLC. The results showed that storage time affects the chemical composition of monosaccharide glucose and fructose as well as the content of carboxylic acids, i.e. organic and free amino acids. The results also indicated that the influence of EOO on composition of canned tomato purée is within the range of changes measured for all other types of cans when the DOS oil is added. Therefore the addition of EOO as natural efficient corrosion inhibitor, as it was found in our previous work, can be recommended for use in production of canned tomato purée.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Croatian Ministry of Science, Education and Sports [grant number 058-0580000-3071].

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge Stazione Sperimentale per l'Industria delle Conserve Alimentari and Croatian Ministry of Science, Education and Sports for their support of our work on canned tomato purée.
